attributes.title: Lack of control and inhibition of goal-inconsistent responses

q1.value: Lack of control and inhibition of goal-inconsistent responses: The role of intentional binding

q3.value: Implicit sense of agency may be regarded as cue that an individual is in implemental, rather than a deliberative mindset. Individuals who implement their goals are expected to experience high sense of agency while choosing goal-consistent actions over the goal-inconsistent alternatives (e.g., an apple over a cookie in case of individuals trying to eat healthy food). This study will examine whether lack of control results in decreased ability to inhibit unwanted food decisions, and whether such a decrease is correlated with a decrease in intentional binding. We predict that prolonged experience of lack of control will result in change from implemental to deliberative mindset decreasing an ability to inhibit goal-inconsistent and reducing implicit sense of agency.

q4.value:
H1. Individuals with experimentally induced lack of control will experience higher – than participants in the full control condition – response conflicts when making decisions between healthy and unhealthy foods.
H2. Individuals with experimentally induced lack of control will show smaller intentional binding than participants in the full control condition.
H3. The measures or response conflict and intentional binding will be negatively correlated.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor and 2 levels (full control vs. lack of control).

q9.value: We will use simple randomization, where each participant will be assigned to one of 2 conditions. Randomization will be conducted by a computer random number generator.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited by research assistants from a population of undergraduate students at the University of Warsaw. Participants will be paid 15PLN (around $4) for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: The target sample size is 102 participants.

q14.value: Our goal war to obtain .08 power to deter medium effect size (d = 0.5) with a one-tailed test at the standard .05 type I error probability.

question.value: We will use the standard version of Behavioral Helplessness Training (see e.g., Soral, Kofta, Bukowski, 2020).

The mouse-tracking paradigm will be used to examine response conflict about healthy and unhealthy foods (see Gillebaart, Schneider, & De Ridder, 2016). Participants will be presented with 20 examples of healthy and unhealthy food items and categorize them as positive or negative by dragging the cursor from the center bottom of the screen to one of the two upper corners of the screen. Both area under the curve (AUC) and reaction times (RT) will be used to measure the magnitude of response conflict. Higher values of both AUC and RT will be interpreted as higher response conflict.  
After each decision a tone will be presented with a delay of 250ms. Following each trial participants will be asked to assess the time interval between response selection and occurrence of tone. Larger responses (in comparison to the fixed value of 250ms) will be interpreted as lower intentional binding and thus lower implicit sense of agency.
For all measures the 3 indices will be created as means across 10 healthy items, 10 unhealthy items, and also all (20) items.

We will use Bayesian t-tests to examine differences between two groups of participants. We will use Bayesian correlation analysis to examine how response conflict and implicit sense of agency are related. We will use sensitivity analysis to examine how the choice of prior affects the results.

q21.value: We will regard Bayes factors higher than 3 as indicating a moderate evidence for our hypotheses. We will use Bayes factors higher than 10 as indicating strong evidence for our hypothesis. We will interpret Bayes factors lower than 3 as non-supportive for our hypotheses.

q22.value: We will use Student t likelihood to account for potential outliers.

q23.value: If a subject does complete all measures, that subject will be removed from the analysis.

attributes.title: Systematic review of prediction models for triaging cov-19 patients
attributes.description: An inventory and critical appraisal of prediction models for COVID-19 triage published in Arxiv, medRxiv, bioRxiv, PubMed, and EMBASE

q1.value: Rapid systematic review of diagnostic and prognostic prediction models in the COVID-19 pandemic

q2.value: Laure Wynants, Ben van Calster, Marc Bonten, Gary Collins, Thomas Debray, Maria Haller, Georg Heinze, Karel GM Moons, Richard Riley, Ewoud Schuit, Luc Smits, Ewout W Steyerberg, Christine Wallisch, Maarten van Smeden

q3.value:
Objective To provide an overview and critical appraisal of published and preprint articles that develop or evaluate clinical prediction models/rules to diagnose COVID-19 infection, including medical imaging studies, or prognosis after COVID-19 diagnosis.

Design Systematic review of prediction modeling studies.

Eligibility criteria for selecting studies Studies of any design that propose or evaluate multivariable models or scoring rules for the diagnosis in suspected cases or prognosis for patients with COVID-19. Two authors independently screened titles and abstracts. Data from included studies were extracted independently by two authors. Risk of bias was assessed using PROBAST (Prediction model Risk Of Bias ASsessment Tool). Data were extracted on the source population, predictors chosen, outcomes, and prediction model performance.

Results 1914 titles were screened. Of these, 44 abstracts were screened. 13 papers are included for critical appraisal.

q4.value: The analysis is descriptive and not testing any hypotheses.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q9.value: This is not a randomized study.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
Papers were included if they developed a multivariable model or scoring system, based on patient level data, to predict a COVID-19 diagnosis or prognosis regardless of prediction horizon (mortality, progression, hospitalization, intensive care admission, illness severity) in individual in- or outpatients. Prediction to assist with COVID-19 screening was also considered. Studies that aimed at modeling disease transmission or case-fatality rates, diagnostic test accuracy and predictor finding studies were excluded. 13 papers were included.

Data extraction on included articles will be done by two independent reviewers, using a standardized data extraction form based on the CHARMS checklist.3 Conflicts will be resolved by a third reviewer (LW or MvS).

q13.value: 13 papers are included, this may be updated if authors we contacted make unpublished work available for inclusion.

q14.value: All papers meeting eligibility criteria were included.

question.value:
•	Population (China, other).
•	Intended timing of model use (screening of patients, ICU admission, etc.).
•	Setting (inpatients, outpatients, suspected cases).
•	Participants: study design, recruitment method, number of centers, inclusion criteria, exclusion criteria, patient age (mean and standard deviation or median and interquartile range), patient sex (n males and percentage).
•	Predictors: list of candidate predictors, number of candidate predictors, number of additional degrees of freedom for candidate predictors, predictors in the final model, number of predictors in the final model, number of additional degrees of freedom in the final model.
•	Outcome: definition of outcome, timing of outcome.
•	Analysis: 
o	Number of participants, number of patients with outcome.
o	Number of participants with any missing predictor/outcome values, handling of missing data.
o	Methods for selection of predictors in multivariable model, modelling method (logistic regression, Cox regression, neural network, tree-based, etc.), method for selection of predictors during multivariable analysis and the criteria used (e.g., p-value used for selection).
o	Handling of categorical and continuous variables.
o	Apparent performance (calibration, discrimination, other).
o	Internal validation (incl. technique used, shrinkage performed, calibration, discrimination, other performance measures).
o	Model presentation (coefficients and confidence intervals presented, final model presented, alternative presentation of the model such as a web-based tool). 
o	External validation (incl. calibration, discrimination, other performance measures).
•	PROBAST risk of bias and applicability items regarding participants, predictors, outcome, analysis, and overall risk of bias and applicability assessment.

Only descriptive statistics. A summary measure (e.g., of the c-statistic) will be computed through meta-analysis if appropriate (i.e., if sufficient independent models for the same prediction problem exist).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Demographics: Demographic information will be collected at T0 instead of at the end of T1 or T2 to prevent fatigued participants from leaving these items blank. Each participant’s age, race, gender, objective-SES measures of education level, employment status, annual household income, and subjective-SES using the MacArthur Scale (Adler & Stewart, 2007) will be reported.

Variables collected for exploratory purposes at T1:

 1. Expectations for reducing or quitting cigarette smoking: Expectations will be assessed with a single item before the manipulation (“How likely do you think it is that you will reduce or quit your cigarette smoking?”)

 2. Incentive value for reducing or quitting cigarette smoking: Incentive value will be assessed with a single item before the manipulation (“How important is it to you to reduce or quit your cigarette smoking?”)

3. Perceived Stress, Perceived Stress Scale (PSS): To assess stress in the past month, we will present participants with three items from the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS; Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein, 1983; e.g., ‘How often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?’; 0 = Never, 4 = Very often).

4. Anxiety and Depression, Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ): To assess symptoms of anxiety and depression in the past two weeks, we will present participants with the four-item Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-4; Kroenke, Spitzer, Williams, & Löwe, 2009; e.g., ‘Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge’; 0 = Not at all, 3 = Nearly every day). 

5. Smoking Dependence Motives: To understand participants’ motives for smoking, we will include 6 items from subscales of the Wisconsin Inventory of Smoking Dependence Motives (WISDM-68; Piper, Federman, Bolt, Smith, Fiore, & Baker, 2004). We will select items from the social/environmental goads sub-scale (e.g., ‘Most of the people I spend time with are smokers’) and the cue exposure/associative processes sub-scale (e.g., 'My life is full of reminders to smoke’). Participants will rate their level of agreement for each statement on a 7-point scale (1 = Not true of me at all, 7 = Extremely true of me). 

6. Nicotine Dependence: Participants will also be asked to indicate how much money they would be willing to pay the next morning for just one cigarette after not being able to get ahold of any. This question is taken from the priority subscale of the Nicotine Dependence Syndrome Scale (NDSS; Shiffman, Waters, & Hickcox, 2004).

7. Cigarette Dependence: To measure cigarette dependence, we will use the 5-item version of the Cigarette Dependence Scale (CDS-5; Etter, Le Houezec, & Perneger, 2003; α = .85). The items will ask participants to rate their addiction to cigarettes, how many cigarettes they smoked per day on average, how soon after waking up do they smoke their first cigarette, how difficult quitting smoking would be, and how strong their urges to smoke were. Responses will be recoded to range from 1 to 5. We will define high cigarette dependence as a composite CDS-5 score of 15 or greater.

8. Smoking Induced Deprivation: To measure tobacco-related financial distress, we'll assess smoking induced deprivation (SID) with a single question reported in the literature asking ‘In the last 30 days, has there been a time when the money you spent on cigarettes resulted in not having enough money for any of these items: housing, food, household utilities, health care, transportation, and necessary clothing?’ (Siahpush, Borland, & Yong, 2007).

9. Smoking Characteristics: Supplementary variables about smoker characteristics will be measured to better characterize the sample. We will ask participants to report if they typically purchase cigarettes by the pack or by the individual cigarette and how much they spend, what age they began smoking, the amount and length of abstinence in days of any quit attempts made in the past year, and other tobacco use.

Variables collected for exploratory purposes at T2:

1. Steps Taken: Participants will be asked to indicate any steps taken to reduce or quit smoking since T0 (e.g., done something to relieve my stress or improve my mood besides smoking a cigarette like deep breathing or talking to a friend; Oettingen & Thorpe, 2010; Mutter et al. 2019).

2. Strategy Use: To measure how well participants remembered and used the MCII or Reasons for Quitting strategies learned at T1, we will ask participants to rate how often they used and thought about it on a 7-point scale (1 = Never, 7 = Every day).

sample.value: We conducted an a-priori G* analysis with the following specifications: effect size f² = 0.0365726, α err prob	= 0.05, power (1-β err prob) = 0.90, number of tested predictors = 1, total number of predictors = 3. Based on this, we will recruit participants until we have at least 290 total participants randomized to condition at Time 1.

analyses.value:
To examine the main hypothesis, we will run a linear regression and we will use an intent-to-treat approach. The outcome will be smoking reduction from Time 1 to Time 2 and the predictors will be condition (0 = control; 1 = MCII), subjective-SES (mean-centered), and the interaction. To formally test the expected pattern of results, we will run a linear contrast at high (+1SD) and low (-1 SD) levels of subjective-SES. We expect a significant effect of condition, such that MCII improves smoking reduction relative to the control, at high but not low levels of subjective-SES. Additionally, we will conduct a version of this analysis using binary logistic regression and the same predictors to test the secondary outcome of smoking cessation. 

Per an intent to treat approach, we will impute missing data at follow-up.

outliers.value:
Eligibility for pre-screener: The T0 survey will only be displayed to Mturk workers who are at least 18 years old, in the United States, and have a high rate of satisfactory performance on prior tasks completed in MTurk (i.e., a HIT approval rate of at least 75%). The age criterion was implemented as a consequence of MTurk requiring all Workers to be at least 18 years old (participants also attested to being at least 18 years of age when providing informed consent). The location and performance criteria were implemented via the Worker Qualifications settings in TurkPrime.

We will exclude pre-screened participants who:
i. At Time 0, are non-smokers, are current smokers of less than 15 cigarettes-per-day, or are not open to changing their cigarette smoking in the next 4 weeks.
ii. At Time 0, fail an attention check (“This is a statement. Please select option number two.”)

dependent.value:
Smoking reduction (primary dependent variable): Smoking reduction will be assessed using self-reported measures of recent (one-week) smoking at Times 1 and 2, according to a Timeline Followback procedure (Robinson, LC Sobell, MB Sobell, and Leo, 2014). The number of cigarettes reported as smoked will be averaged across all 7 days, for a composite score in units of cigarettes-per-day (CPD). Smoking reduction will be defined as the difference in average CPD between Time 1 and Time 2, such that higher scores indicate greater reduction. We will use these reports to compute smoking reduction scores, with an intent-to-treat approach.

Smoking cessation (secondary dependent variable): At Time 2, we will assess smoking cessation according to a one-week abstinence criterion (see Fiore, Bailey, & Cohen, 2000, Treating Tobacco Use & Dep; Etter et al., 2003), measured with the following item: “Did you smoke tobacco during the past 7 days (even one puff of cigarette, cigar, pipe, etc)?” (0 = no, 1 = yes).

conditions.value:
Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of two strategy conditions after consenting at Time 1: MCII or control. Both strategies will be the same as used in Mutter et al. 2019. The control condition will be based on smokefree.gov and Motivational Interviewing techniques. Respective strategies will be taught at the Time 1 session as a brief online intervention.

Our other key independent variable is subjective-SES, measured by the MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status (Adler & Stewart, 2007).

hypothesis.value:
We hypothesized that an online delivery of MCII (mental contrasting with implementation intentions) would reduce smoking more compared to an active control strategy among smokers of high subjective-SES but not among smokers of low subjective-SES. We expect the same pattern when smoking cessation is the outcome. 

This is an exploratory hypothesis: subjective-SES will be used as an exploratory variable based on an exploratory re-analysis of the dataset from a previous randomized controlled trial by Mutter et al., 2019.

Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of two strategy conditions after consenting at Time 1: MCII or control. Both strategies will be the same as used in Mutter et al. 2019. The control condition will be based on smokefree.gov and Motivational Interviewing techniques. Respective strategies will be taught at the Time 1 session as a brief online intervention.

Our other key independent variable is subjective-SES, measured by the MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status (Adler & Stewart, 2007).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
We hypothesized that an online delivery of MCII (mental contrasting with implementation intentions) would reduce smoking more compared to an active control strategy among smokers of high subjective-SES but not among smokers of low subjective-SES. We expect the same pattern when smoking cessation is the outcome. 

This is an exploratory hypothesis: subjective-SES will be used as an exploratory variable based on an exploratory re-analysis of the dataset from a previous randomized controlled trial by Mutter et al., 2019.

attributes.title: Underestimation of exponential growth and severity perception of SARS-CoV2

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Experimental evidence of exponential growth bias on severity ratings of SARS-CoV2.

other.value: If the experimental manipulation does not provide an effect on the manipulation check, we will use the MC as a correlational factor that we assume to correlate with the severity ratings. In addition, we will control the experimental main effects for gender, income, highesteducation, political ideology, self-assessment for being a vulnerable person in the corona crisis, and having received a positive diagnosis in one's household.

sample.value: Based on a power analysis assuming a small effect, we target a sample of 400 people. They will be recruited on Prolific.ac, and participants are restricted to the US, excluding NY and CA.

analyses.value:
We will first test the effect of the IV on the Manipulation check. In the manipulation check, we ask people to estimate the development of the curve on seven points in time (5 day-steps, ranging from March 22 to April 22). Based on people's estimate, we can infer the growth factor that they assume. We expect that this factor is larger in the "steep" compared to the "flat" condition. 

Then, we will test if the assignment to the experimental condition has an impact on the severity ratings.

outliers.value: We will exclude the people who fail to provide a correct answer to the attention check, embedded into the manipulation check. People need to fill in the number 12345 to be included in the dataset.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable is a four-item severity scale, which participants answer using a Likert-Scale ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5). The items are:
People's fear of the new coronavirus is exaggerated.		
There is too much coverage about the coronavirus in all media as well as social media.					
The new coronavirus is not more dangerous to humans compared to related viruses (e.g., SARS, the seasonal influenza, etc.)						
I think that the mortality from the new coronavirus is similar to other related virses (e.g., SARS, the seasonal influenza, etc.).

The DV will be a composite measure of the items, given high enough reliability (alpha = 0.70). If this is not the case, we will conduct a exploratory factor analysis to form a measure based on less than the four items.

conditions.value: Participants will be assigned to one of only two conditions, steep versus flat. The manipulation is done by "stretching" the graph to make it appear less steep. The graphs display the actual corona-infections in the United States from February 26 to March 15.

hypothesis.value: We hypothesize if experimental inductions of expontial growth bias via the perception of related statistical graphs increases severity ratings of SARS-CoV2

attributes.title: Understanding digital hoarding: The mechanisms and implications in relation to wellbeing.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: 'Understanding digital hoarding: The mechanisms and implications in relation to wellbeing'. This study will look into the mechanisms that drive digital hoarding behaviour, as well as identify the corresponding effect on psychological wellbeing. This analysis aims to expand the theoritical underpinning, as well as the real life implications of digital hoarding behaviour. The secondary analysis component will look into the degree to which the confounds of OCD and physical hoarding affect the primary analysis. This secondary analysis will investigate how distinctive digital hoarding appears when similar constructs are considered as confounding factors.

other.value:
Analysis 2: (Multiple Regression)
                   DV: Digital Hoarding Scores, OCD Scores, Physical Hoarding Scores
                   Measured: Digital Hoarding Questionnaire (Digital Hoarding Scores), 
                   Obsessive-Compulsive Inventory Revised Questionnaire (OCD Scores) ,
                   Saving-Inventory-Revised Questionnaire (Physical Hoarding Scores)

                   IV: Wellbeing Scores, Exective Function Scores, and Personality Traits.
                   Measured: PERMA-Profiler (Wellbeing Scores), Webexec (Executive Functioning 
                   Scores), Big-Five Inventory (Personality Traits).

sample.value: 153 participants are aimed to be collected. This number is in accordance with G*Power estimates to identify an appropriate sample size in order to conduct the analysis.

analyses.value: Multiple regression will be used to address the primary analysis.

outliers.value: Any incomplete data will be removed from the dataset. In regards to outliers, extreme outliers will be winsorized to 3SD above and below the mean.

dependent.value:
Analysis 1:
                   DV: Digital Hoarding Scores
                   Measured: Digital Hoarding Questionnaire.

conditions.value: The study is survey based so all participants will complete all questionnaires.

hypothesis.value: The research aims to address several key issues raised within the research area of understanding digital hoarding. The first aim will be to identify how executive function and personality influence digital hoarding behaviour. It is predicted that poorer executive functioning scores will predict greater digital hoarding behaviour; personality will also affect digital hoarding scores. The second aim will be to investigate how digital hoarding behaviour influences wellbeing. It is predicted that greater wellbeing scores will be associated with lower digital hoarding scores. Finally, the third aim will be to address how substantially physical hoarding and OCD tendencies confound digital hoarding behaviour. It is predicted that physical hoarding, as well as digital hoarding, will significantly contribute to the severity of digital hoarding behaviour.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Relationship Between Math and Reading Subcomponents

sample.value: This study tested 59 participants, with a total of 31 children and 28 mothers. These are all the currently available data from a larger project (osf.io/e2mq5).

analyses.value:
All of the analyses will be Pearson correlations between the variables. Because we did not use standardized scores, we will control for age in all subsequent analyses. We will also control for multiple comparisons using a Bonferroni correction in all analyses. We will calculate all pairwise correlations between the six math and reading subcomponents and the three domain general skills, for children and adults separately. 
Partial correlations will be used to investigate if the correlations between math and reading subskills still hold when controlling for domain general influences. We will only further analyze the significant cross-domain correlations. 
To investigate age-related effects, the correlations between the subcomponents will be compared between the children and adult sample using a Williams-Steiger test (http://quantpsy.org/corrtest/corrtest.htm). This test allows to investigate whether two correlation coefficients are significantly different from each other.

outliers.value: Participants had to be fluent English speakers, with no developmental delays or learning disorders (in other words, they had to be typically developing individuals). The children also had to be biologically related to the adult (mother) who participated in the study.

dependent.value:
Each variable had its own task. Each of the measures are briefly explained and described.

Reading abilities
	Fluency. To measure reading fluency, the participants completed the Sight Word Efficiency task from the Test of Word Reading Efficiency II (Torgesen, Wagner, & Rashotte, 1999). In this standardized task, participants are asked to read aloud as many existing English words as possible during a set time limit of 45 seconds. Examinees are given one point per word that they correctly read within the time limit, with a maximum score of 104 points. The measure that will be used for analyses is the number of correctly read words per second.
	Comprehension. To assess reading comprehension, the “Passage Comprehension” subtest of the Woodcock-Johnson Test of Achievement III (Woodcock, McGrew, & Mather, 2001) was used. In this standardized task, participants are asked to read short passages of text and to fill in a blank space with a word that fits the context. The participant is awarded one point for each correct answer, with a maximum of 47 points. The participant continued the task until they reached the last item, or until they reached the ceiling rule of six. The ceiling rule states the number of consecutive incorrect answers that the participant needs to reach for the examiner to end the task. 
	Decoding. The standardized Phonemic Decoding Efficiency subtest (Test of Word Reading Efficiency II) (Torgesen, Wagner, & Rashotte, 2012) asks participants to read aloud as many pseudo-words as possible during a set time limit of 45 seconds. They are given one point per correctly read pseudo-word, with a maximum of 84 points. The measure that will be used for analyses is the number of correctly read words per second.

Math abilities
	Fluency. The Math Fluency subtest from the Woodcock-Johnson Test of Achievement III (Woodcock, McGrew, & Mather, 2001) is used to measure the participants’ arithmetic fluency. In this standardized task, participants are asked to solve as many arithmetic exercises during a set time limit of three minutes. They receive one point for each addition, subtraction, and multiplication problem that they solved correctly within the time limit, with a maximum score of 160 points. The measure that will be used for analyses is the number of correctly solved items per second.
	Calculations. The standardized Calculation subtest from the Woodcock-Johnson Test of Achievement III (Woodcock, McGrew, & Mather, 2001) requires the participants to complete as many calculation problems as possible. These calculation exercises are more complex than the simple arithmetic problems that are used in the fluency task. The participants solve as many calculation problems as they can without any time limit and the task ends when the participant either completes all 45 problems, or when they reach the ceiling rule of six. One point is awarded for every correct answer, with a maximum of 45 points.
	Word problems. To assess word problem-solving abilities, the Applied Problems subtest from the Woodcock-Johnson Test of Achievement III was used (Woodcock, McGrew, & Mather, 2001). In this standardized task, participants are asked to solve mathematical word problems. The experimenter reads a word problem and the participant gives a verbal response. They are given paper and pencil to perform calculations if necessary. The participants either finish the task to completion or are stopped when they reach the ceiling rule of six. They are awarded one point per correct answer, with a maximum of 63 points.

Domain general fluency
	Two versions of the Rapid Automatized Naming (RAN) (Wolf, Denckla, 2005) were used to test domain-general fluency abilities: colors and letters. In these tasks, participants are asked to quickly name aloud a series of 50 familiar items presented in random order on a page, making five lines of ten items. The participant has to name them sequentially as fast as possible. The examiner records the time it takes to name all 50 items on the sheets and the number of errors that the participant makes. The participant started with the color RAN, followed by the letter RAN. Participants’ final scores were based on the number of correctly named items per second. The measure that will be used for analyses is the average of the scores of both the color and letter RAN.

Intelligence
	Verbal intelligence. The WASI Vocabulary task (Wechsler, 2011) was used to measure verbal intelligence. In this standardized task, participants are asked to define and describe words that are presented visually or orally. Responses are awarded a score of 0, 1, or 2, depending on the quality of the answer. Testing is stopped after the participants receive three consecutive scores of 0. The score is based on the number of points they receive throughout the task, with a maximum score of 53 points. 
	Nonverbal intelligence. The WASI Matrix Reasoning (Wechsler, 2011) asks the participant to look at a matrix with a missing section and to complete that matrix by selecting the correct response out of the five options that are shown. Examinees get one point per correct answer and reach the ceiling level after three consecutive incorrect answers. The score is based on the number of points they receive throughout the task, with a maximum score of 30 points.

conditions.value: N/A – all participants perform the same battery of tasks.

hypothesis.value:
The relationship between math and reading remains a relatively unexplored territory. Although these skills are often thought of as separate domains of learning, studies have shown high comorbidity rates between reading and math difficulties, suggesting a relationship between the two (Landerl, & Moll, 2010). Along with behavioral data, genetic studies have found that genes related to one learning disability (e.g., difficulties in math) are also likely to affect other learning disabilities (e.g., difficulties in reading), offering genetic evidence for an overlap between math and reading (Plomin, & Kovas, 2005). A third branch of support for a relationship between reading and math comes from neuroimaging studies. Neural activity levels in frontal and parietal areas, along with white matter integrity in the corona radiata and arcuate fasciculus tracts, did not differ between dyslexic, dyscalculic or comorbid individuals (Peters, Bulthé, Daniels, Op de Beeck, & De Smedt, 2018; Moreau, Wilson, McKay, Nihill, & Waldie, 2018). These results support the potential overlap between math and reading deficits at the neural level.
When studies devote attention to the relationship between math and reading, or use math and reading as control measures, they often limit their measurements to fluency measures of both skills (see e.g., Koponen, Aunola, Ahonen, & Nurmi, 2007). Fluency measures are quick and practical, which is why they are such appealing variables to use. However, fluency is but one of the many subcomponents of math and reading, and stating that math and reading are related after only measuring for fluency could lead to  large overgeneralization regarding the similarities between reading and math. Fluency is only the tip of the iceberg in terms of potential relationships between the subcomponents of math and reading. It is known that reading fluency and math fluency are highly correlated (Balhinez, & Shaul, 2019), yet no further efforts have been made to examine the potential relationships between additional subcomponents. Reading and math also include (but are not limited to) word problem solving (the ability to filter information and follow correct steps to obtain an answer) and calculations (the ability to apply rules to more complex math problems) for math, and decoding (the ability to phonologically decode new words/non-words) and reading comprehension (understanding the context and the conveyed message that you are reading) for reading. This study will explore in greater depth the relationship between a large selection of math and reading subcomponents, along with domain general measures.
First, we will examine the relationship within the subcomponents of the math and reading domains. We will study if all three math subcomponents under study (fluency, word problem solving and calculations) are related to one another. In addition, we will test if the three reading subcomponents measured in this study (fluency decoding and reading comprehension) are related to one another. We hypothesize that both math and reading domains will be correlated within each other.
Second, this study will investigate the relationship between the math and reading subcomponents. We hypothesize that the math subcomponents will be correlated to the reading subcomponents, which would suggest some overlap between the two domains of learning (Balhinez, & Shaul, 2019; Hart, Petrill, Thompson, & Plomin, 2009) 
Third, this study will identify the role that the domain general skills play in these relationships between the subcomponents (general fluency, verbal intelligence, nonverbal intelligence). We hypothesize that math and reading fluency will be positively correlated with domain general fluency (Koponen, Salmi, Eklund, & Aro, 2013). We also hypothesize that verbal and nonverbal intelligence will be correlated with all six math and reading subcomponents, as it was found in literature (Hart, Petrill, Thompson, & Plomin, 2009). 
Fourth, this study will attempt to detect any potential group differences between children and adults. It is possible that the patterns of correlations between the measures differ as a function of chronological age. One study tested the relationship between IQ and reading ability in 5-12 year old children. They found that the levels of association between reading and intelligence increased with age. Although this current study has older participants (10-14 years old children and much older adults), we predict that it will also show differences between the children and the adult sample correlations (Birch, & Belmont, 1965).

summary.value:
Update to initial preregistration:

In our initial preregistration, we planned to test the six components of relationship quality (satisfaction, commitment, trust, intimacy, love, and passion) separately. However, upon revisiting Sample A we noted that the components were all very strongly correlated (rs = .51-.83, with all but two correlations greater than .63). This led us to consider relationship quality as a global composite of the six components. In analyses with the relationship quality composite, the same pattern of results described in our initial preregistration emerged again. Thus, we decided to focus on overall relationship quality for our confirmatory Sample B analyses.

We have also decided to run an auxiliary analysis involving relationship length as a covariate. Self-expansion opportunities are likely to be more frequent early on in relationships, so it is possible that any associations with self-expansion potential may vary based on how long someone has been in a relationship with their partner.

We will still use multiple regression to analyze Sample B. We will run two models: Model 1 will include our primary variables of interest, and Model 2 will add relationship length.

registration_responses.summary:
Update to initial preregistration:

In our initial preregistration, we planned to test the six components of relationship quality (satisfaction, commitment, trust, intimacy, love, and passion) separately. However, upon revisiting Sample A we noted that the components were all very strongly correlated (rs = .51-.83, with all but two correlations greater than .63). This led us to consider relationship quality as a global composite of the six components. In analyses with the relationship quality composite, the same pattern of results described in our initial preregistration emerged again. Thus, we decided to focus on overall relationship quality for our confirmatory Sample B analyses.

We have also decided to run an auxiliary analysis involving relationship length as a covariate. Self-expansion opportunities are likely to be more frequent early on in relationships, so it is possible that any associations with self-expansion potential may vary based on how long someone has been in a relationship with their partner.

We will still use multiple regression to analyze Sample B. We will run two models: Model 1 will include our primary variables of interest, and Model 2 will add relationship length.

attributes.title: Cultural Appropriation and Perceptions of Celebration

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to examine whether, among White perceivers, threats to moral identity (vs. control) will influence perceptions of cultural celebration and of cultural appropriation.

q4.value:
Two-way interactions (Threat X Target Race) on perceptions of cultural appropriation and celebration are expected. 

Specifically, in this sample of White perceivers, threats to moral identity (vs. control) will:
a)	increase the extent to which the White target is perceived as celebratory and decrease the extent to which the White target is perceived as appropriative. 
b)	Increase the extent to which the Black target is perceived as appropriative and reduce the extent to which the Black target is perceived as celebratory. 

Predictions for evidentiary standards are similar: Threat will

c)	reduce evidentiary standards for appraisals of cultural celebration in the White (relative to Black) target condition, and 
d)	increase evidentiary standards for appraisals of cultural appropriation in the White (relative to Black) target condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study will use a 2 (Threat: Threat vs. Control) x 2 (Target Race) between-subjects design.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to conditions via a randomizer on Qualtrics.com

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via Amazon's Mechanical Mturk. We will exclude participants who do not complete the study. We will also exclude with duplicate IP addresses, those who fail the ethnicity check, and those who do not follow instructions.

q13.value: We will recruit 240 participants who self-identify as White-American, who are over 18 years old, and who reside in the United States.

q14.value: Assuming a medium effect size (ΔR2 = .05), α = .05, and 85% power in a 2 x 2 ANOVA model, I will recruit will recruit 240 White adults.

question.value:
Morality Threat (Threat vs. Control Condition)

Target Race (White target vs. Black target)

Target Race Manipulation. Participants will be asked to read and evaluate an online article. The information in the article will be consistent throughout the conditions, except for the manipulations of target race. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the White target condition or the Black target condition. In the White target condition, participants will read about a White target engaged with Black-American culture. In the Black target condition, participants will read about a Black target engaged with White-American culture. The targets will be Black or White artists who produced art that references the racial/ethnic cultural group to which they do not belong. Each participant will be exposed to only one scenario.

Participants will then complete a 4 -item measure of perceptions of cultural celebration (e.g. “This person is celebrating/honoring/commemorating Black/White culture [tailored to target race,”) and perceptions of cultural appropriation (e.g. “This person is appropriating/copying/taking from/ Black/White culture [tailored to target race], “,”)  Participants will respond to both measures on a 7-point Likert-type scale from 1 = Strongly Disagree ; 7 = Strongly Agree).

Participants will also complete a measure of evidentiary standards, which will assess cultural appropriation standards (e.g. “Please indicate what percentage of (source group) White-Americans/Black-Americans would be harmed culturally, socially or economically by this scenario for you to consider this to be an act of cultural appropriation?”) and cultural celebration standards (“Please indicate what percentage of (source group) White-Americans/Black-Americans would benefit culturally, socially or economically by this scenario for you to consider this to be an act of cultural celebration?” ).

Perceptions of Appropriation (1 = Strongly Disagree to 7 =Strongly Agree; Mosley & Biernat, in review, JPSP): 
1.	This person is appropriating Black/White culture.
2.	This person is copying Black/White culture.
3.	This person is taking from Black/White culture.
4.	This person is displaying an element of culture that is not their own.
Perceptions of Celebration (1 = Strongly Disagree to 7 =Strongly Agree) This person is appropriating Black/White culture.
1.	This person is celebrating Black/White culture.
2.	This person is appreciating Black/White culture.
3.	This person is honoring Black/White culture.
4.	This person is commemorating Black/White culture.
Evidentiary Standards (0-10%, 10-25%, 25-40%, 40-60%, 60-75%, 75-90%, and 90-100%; Miron, Branscombe, & Biernat, 2010)

•	“Please indicate what percentage of (source group) White-Americans/Black-Americans would be harmed culturally, socially or economically by this scenario for you to consider this to be an act of cultural appropriation?” 

•	“Please indicate what percentage of (source group) White-Americans/Black-Americans would benefit culturally, socially or economically by this scenario for you to consider this to be an act of cultural celebration?” 

Transition back to threat manipulation. Participants will read the following instructions,” Earlier in this study, you chose the following statement (Option 1/2). Please take a few moments to write down the reasons that you chose this statement.”

Threat manipulation check. (Effron, 2012; Study 1). Participants in both conditions will complete a manipulation check to indicate how concerned that the writing task they just did in the study might make them “look bad” (1= Not at all; 7 = Very much).
Scores on dependent measures will each be submitted to a 2 x 2 between subjects Univariate Analysis of Variance. We will also examine simple effects.

q21.value: We will use p < .05 to examine statistical significance.

q22.value: Participants will be recruited via Amazon's Mechanical Mturk. We will exclude participants who do not complete the study. We will also exclude with duplicate IP addresses, those who fail the ethnicity check, and those who do not follow instructions.

q23.value: Participants with missing data will be excluded from analysis.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Risk perception of COVID-19/coronavirus > Finite Pool of Worry

other.value:
We are interested in the relationship between levels of worry about COVID-19 specifically, and participants’ levels of risk perception of the virus, their level of preparedness (e.g. have they taken action to wear a face mask or wash their hands more often), the perceived efficacy (e.g. do they feel their personal actions can make a difference), their specific experiences with the virus (e.g. if they or a family member have had the virus or not, or whether they have experience financial or social disruption do to it), their exposure to various forms of communication about the virus, and their general levels of social trust, trust in government/scientists/medical professionals etc, and perceived effectiveness of/satisfaction with the official response that have been taken so far to deal with the pandemic.  These relationships will be compared across time points and across countries where appropriate.

Finally, we will explore whether participant numerical ability and socio-economic status moderate the results of any of the main or exploratory analyses.

sample.value: We will sample 700 participants per country, providing 95% power at alpha level 0.05 for small effects.

analyses.value:
We will run generalised linear models (e.g. OLS, ANOVA, ANCOVA) and post-hoc tests where appropriate to:

-	Examine for differences in levels of worry about the various risks

-	Examine whether levels of worry between the different risks vary between countries.

-	Examine whether the total amount of worry (the pool of worry) within a country remains the same size between different time points.

-	Examine whether rising worry about coronavirus/COVID-19 specifically is compensated by a decline in level of worry in the other risks.  We will examine these rise and decline patterns between countries.

All post-hoc tests will be run using Tukey’s HSD where possible, in order to correct for multiple comparisons.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who do not complete our survey. Additionally, we will exclude participants who fail an attention check (i.e. a measure that asks participants to indicate the info that was provided in an intervention text used in a different part of the survey that will host the questions discussed in this preregistration; as those participants who cannot provide this information likely did not read the text which makes their data not-usable). We will also screen the data for suspicious scoring patterns across the survey (such as scoring “7” on a long consecutive series of items, including reverse coded items), and may exclude people with such scoring patterns.

dependent.value:
On a scale of 1-7, how worried are you personally about the following issues at present [Not at all worried to very worried]?
•	Climate change
•	Coronavirus (COVID-19)
•	Political disagreement
•	Immigration
•	Unemployment
•	Terrorism
•	Air pollution
•	Crime

conditions.value: This is not an experimental study; all participants will answer all the questions.

hypothesis.value:
In this study we are interested to explore how levels of worry about COVID-19 relate to levels of worry about other risks (e.g. climate change, political disagreement, air pollution, immigration, unemployment, terrorism, crime). We plan to do this in two ways. 

Firstly, comparing levels of concern on a range of risks between different populations where the COVID-19 pandemic is at different levels.  Secondly, by comparing levels of concern on the same range of risks over time within a country.  Our first hypothesis is that as worry for one risk increases, there will be a compensatory decrease in worry about another risk.  Our second is that, resultantly, the sum of participants’ worry ratings across all risks will remain relatively constant between populations in different countries and across time.  Within this finite pool of worry, however, the distribution of concern will vary depending on the status of the pandemic (spatially and temporally) as well as personal psychological factors related to the pandemic.
